segments.text: Bill Tift at the University of California, University of Arizona.
Well, he's from the University of Arizona, but we're currently at the Student Union of the University of California.
Okay, so let's get started at the beginning, and Bill, for the record, give your full name.
William Grant Tift.
And where and when were you born?
April 5th, 1932 in Derby, Connecticut.
How did you first get interested in astronomy?
This has to do with the history of planetary astronomy.
I never wanted to be anything else.
I became interested in science or knew I was going to be a scientist about fourth grade in school in astronomy by the time I was in eighth grade.
And through a local amateur astronomer, elderly lady in my hometown, I met Dirk Brouwer at Yale.

the next major step well in various amateur activities AAVSO things like that Westinghouse Science Talent Search I was one of the trip winners in 1950 to Washington and got to know Harlow Shapley Harvard was the obvious place to go to get undergraduate training and so I went to Harvard as an undergraduate and you were an astronomy major I was an astronomy major which is kind of rare well there were a number of us several other names that are
Well, one in planetary astronomy is one of my roommates was Fred Franklin at CFA.
He's, I believe, in planetary astronomy.
Yes, and I interviewed him in England.
We were roommates at Harvard.
And Dick Sears, who's known in astronomy, was one of the...
So we had astronomy majors in those days.
When did you get your bachelor's degree?
Okay, and then where'd you go to grad school?
Caltech.
Why did you pick Caltech?
Because astronomy was disintegrating at Harvard.
That was when Bach left Harvard and it switched from an observational institution in the Shapley Revolution.
When Shapley resigned and the Southern Hemisphere Observatory was potentially being closed and things like that, it was not a time to go on in observational astronomy and
Caltech was the obvious place where first-rate observational astronomy was being done.
So I went to Caltech.
And what was your thesis and who was your thesis advisor for your PhD?
OK. My thesis was on the photometry of the nuclei, nuclear regions of galaxies, well, photometry of galaxies on an eight-color system.
My advisor was Art Code.
He was at Caltech at that time and then later left Caltech.
I guess he went back to Wisconsin as director at that time.
Bill Baum was my other sort of advisor.
I say sort of advisor because I actually saw art code only twice during my thesis, the beginning and at one intermediate point.
I had one discussion with Bill Baum.
Otherwise, I pretty much did it myself.
When did you get your PhD?
Okay, and what did you do then?
I went as a postdoc to Australia to work on Magellanic Cloud problems.
With Bach?
Well, Bach was director then, and it was through Bach that I made the arrangements.
But again, it was a program I designed myself.
I wasn't working specifically with anyone.
Okay, now, so when did you leave Australia?
Okay, Australia, I was a two-year National Science Foundation postdoc.
I left there in 1959 and finished the last few months of the postdoc at...
Caltech, and then I had arranged a job in Nashville with Carl Seifert at the University of, well, at Vanderbilt University, Dyer Observatory.
Unfortunately, Carl Seifert had been killed in an automobile accident.
As a matter of fact, it was
It happened an hour before I arrived in Nashville for my first visit.
I was met by a graduate student, in fact, Charles Tolbert, well-known in astronomy, who told me that Carol had just been killed in an automobile accident.
I went to Seaford's funeral.
But that changed what was to be a three-year appointment working in high-latitude blue stars

to a one-year appointment, immediately looking for a job, which is when, well, I had previously met John Hall and was interested in possibilities at Lowell, and so I immediately picked up that thread.
And since Harold Johnson had just left Lowell and they had just acquired the Ohio State 69-inch telescope,
And I had the kind of credentials both in photometry and experience with large telescopes.
So basically I was offered Errol Johnson's job at Lowell.
So I was actually at Vanderbilt then only for one year.
Okay, when you got to Lowell, what was the place like?
Well, it's a beautiful place to live and a beautiful place to enjoy yourself.
Perhaps one of the most wonderful settings and pleasant places to live.
But I think the one thing which is most obvious about Lowell, was obvious then, was the extremely tight budget under which they operated.
The question of the controls of the
Lowell estate and a fairly small section, a portion of which was devoted to maintaining the observatory.
And although I don't know many of the details, I know there was a lot of concern about whether any of the additional estate money would become available to astronomy.

I never really went into any discussions on this, but there was a lot of concern as to how you could operate an effective modern observatory on the extremely small amounts of money which were available.

You mentioned yesterday that early on in the space program, when it was about time you were getting involved, the powers that be or whoever decided that they really didn't want to get involved with the space program because it didn't have the base
on which to do it, which is kind of surprising in that later that they did get the Planetary Data Center and everything.
Could you say that for the record?
Well, for various reasons, part of them personal in my own life, I was going through approaching divorce and so on.
It was a certain feeling on my part that I needed some change.
The space program was developing, and I wrote a letter at one point to the Institute for

of Astrophysics, or whatever it is, the NASA Institute in New York City, I believe, and expressing interest in space astronomy, and was referred to Jocelyn Gill and, I forget his first name, Foster's division in NASA on manned space astronomy, and
They invited me back to Washington for a while.
I went back as a consultant for a couple of months.
What year was this, roughly?
It had been around 19... Well, I went to Lowell in 61.
Probably the original correspondence here was in 62, possibly as late as 63.
When I came back from Washington, I was quite interested in the space program and potentially interested in applying to the astronaut program.
In fact, I did apply later in 1965.
But...

I remember having discussions with John Hall and expressing my interest in the space program and getting this feedback or concern that, well, this really was not the kind of direction that they felt that they could support the program.
That if I was interested in going into this, that perhaps this wasn't the proper base to operate from.
And of course, they had hired me.
in a completely different context, basically, to use, I mean, to do photometry with some of the large, their newer large telescope, well, the 6090s.
Not that it was that great a telescope, because it wasn't at that time, until they redid it a few years later.
And made it into a, what, a 72-inch?
72-inch, with a quality mirror.
I spent a lot of time
Well, there were two problems.
One, the 69-inch was not a high-quality telescope.
You couldn't do imagery with it.
The images tended to distort rapidly as a function of temperature changes.
I remember doing a lot of installation work on the telescope, trying to control the figure on the mirror.
And also, because of the very low budgets at Lolo, they had very little instrumentation.
There was no equipment, really, to go with it.
One reason they had hired me was I did have my own part of my own photometer.
Harold Johnson had taken all the equipment with him when he left, and there really was no working equipment.
I got a small O&R grant with which I built up a working photometer and did use the 69-inch to extend the work that I had done as my dissertation.
That was my main
new scientific research that I did at Lowell.
But in parallel, I was developing this interest in the space program.
And it was that aspect that, well, John Lowell specifically was a little apprehensive about whether this was an appropriate type of development that Lowell wanted to support.
Let me just get something in for the record.
When did you leave Lowell?
1964, essentially.
Initially, it was halftime, I think, from July to October of 64.
I was halftime at Lowell and halftime at Arizona.
And then in October of 64, I was full-time at Arizona.
Where you have been since then.
Where I've been there since then, that's correct.
I went there as associate professor and was promoted to full professor in 1973.
when you were at Lowell.

Now, Lowell's, of course, famous to the public for its planetary and particularly Mars studies, but of course they always did, right from the very beginning, a lot of stellar and galactic work, for which, of course, they didn't get the credit that they deserved.
But when you were there, what was the attitude towards planetary versus stellar and galactic and extragalactic work?

Well, there was a strong support, I think, or a feeling that the work that Harold had done and the study of star clusters, there wasn't much experience there in galaxies, although I remember having discussions with some of the U.S.
Naval Observatory people.
There had been some interesting work that had been done by, hmm, what was his name?
some multicolor photography or multicolor imagery that had been done on galaxies at Naval Observatory.
I think they were quite enthusiastic, actually, about the work that I was doing on galaxy photometry.
It fit rather nicely into the kind of things that Harold had been initially exploring.
I'd also done work in star clusters and things, so I had a lot in common in principle with the kinds of things that Harold Johnson had been doing.
And I think they were very enthusiastic about that kind of work.
I encountered very little feeling that Lowell had a planetary orientation, or there certainly was no pressure in any sense to be doing anything that was connected with planetary work.
I think they considered their work potentially quite broad-based.
One of the very visible programs there was Henry Giklis' work on proper motions of red faint stars, and I actually was considering some observations of some of the proper motion stars.
I'd say it was a fairly broad-based program, stellar, extragalactic, and obviously planetary, but that wasn't an aspect that I had much connection.
Did you ever feel that you were considered by real astronomers to be second rate because you were at Lowell instead of, say, Mount Holson?
No, I didn't have that feeling at all.
I thought Lowell was a highly respected observatory.
It was recognized that they had budgetary or monetary problems.
But, for example, my request for an O&R grant was very well received.
And Lowell, I think, was a very respected observatory.
And the people that were there, not that there weren't very many of us, but Bill Sinton was well-known.
And, of course, Harold Johnson had been extremely well-known.
It was a small group, but I think my general impression was highly regarded.
Now, you overlap with some of the real old-timers there, and that's what I want to hit you for.
Yeah, yeah.
Of the Slipher brothers, I knew EC moderately.
That is, I met him a couple of times, had a few discussions with him.
Vesto, I saw a few times.
He was not around the observatory very much.
And that was really before I got into my modern work in galaxies.
In a way, I wish I'd had a chance to have actually talked to some of them about some of the early redshift work that they did.
I never actually had any direct contact on that.
For the record, of the two brothers, E.C.
was the one who did what?
The two Slipher brothers.
Well, again, you probably know.
I mean, I don't know the history.
Which one was the Mars guy?
Well, I assume EC was more of the planetary oriented, and Vesto a little more.
Well, I know Vesto, I believe, was the one who did the actual ridge observations.

interesting in that if you go back into elementary textbooks of 10 or 20 years ago, it's always Hubble, Hubble, Hubble, and now people have been getting their act together, and they note that it was really Slipher that did it.
Slipher did the actual first observations.
That's correct.
Slipher was the one who made the observations, though I believe it's fair to say it was Hubble that recognized the significance.
And I don't really know what the communication chains were between...
I mean, they obviously knew each other, and I think it...
Any material or information that was collected by Schleifer became known and was used, at least as a starting point, for Hubble.
What exactly how it influenced Hubble's beginning, I have really no idea.

But it puzzles me in a way, and that's why I wish I had known at the time what I was going to be doing later, because it would have been very interesting to talk to the Schleifer brothers about what were their original motivations for doing this, and what were their impressions.
Unfortunately, I have no idea.
They obviously didn't pursue it or follow it up the way Hubble did.
So whether they considered it just a curiosity or whether they really thought deeply about what this might mean, I don't know.
But they preceded the knowledge of what they were looking at.
And I believe part of the original motivation for their observations were undoubtedly the idea that perhaps galaxies were
We've seen this in the literature, but again, I don't have it as a direct statement for this life.
Galaxies were considered as possible solar systems in formation.
That was one of the old concepts.
Did you ever meet Lamplin?
No.
Because there was a lot of radiometry that went on in the 20s and 30s.
I knew Edison Pettit, but that was back through...
In fact, Edison Pettit was the man who built the photometer that I took to Australia.
or built the cold box, to my specifications.
But he was the only really old...
I guess he was retired from Mount Wilson, but he was still running his machine shop in Pasadena, and I was referred to him and made arrangements for him to build my photometer.
But again, I never had any in-depth conversations with these people.
I've heard various stories about how the old work was done, but... Well, let's hear an old story.

Well, like the first observations of photometry on the 100-inch telescope when they used a ballistic galvanometer as the operating across the 10-foot width of the Newtonian platform on the 100-inch telescope to get the first photometric deflections that were used in some of the early galaxy photometry that people like Pettit and Stevens and Whitford and so on were doing.
at Lowell when you were there, what did the people on the staff think of Percival Lowell?
Well, I had the impression that he was a very highly respected founder of the observatory.
I never heard anything negative.
And the old library there, the tours that they held, his founding of the observatory, his original
connection with Mars and so on was always very highly regarded, as far as I could tell.
I was never directly, I'd say, involved in any of this.
I never remember any conversations relating to Lowell.
I had a number of conversations with the, what's the man who administered the estate?
executor, not executor, but...
Sole trustee or something, wasn't it?
Sole trustee, yes.
Was his nephew or something like that?
Yes, his nephew.
Roger Lowell Putnam was the trustee, and I remember going for a hike up Mount Humphreys.
We didn't get to the top, but I remember I went on a hike with him.
Again, the main theme that came through was...
Lack of money.
I never detected anything but enthusiasm for doing the best astronomy we can at this institution, but we don't have much money.
How did the townsfolk treat the observatory and the astronomers there?
My impression, again, was that this was a highly respected institution and
Again, I never detected any animosity or any feeling that this was anything but a real nice thing to have in town.
And it was a standard viewing place.
People would drive up the drive, and it was always considered one of the best places to look over the surrounding area.
Mars Hill was certainly a local institution.
I just flew over it Saturday, and there was a hole in the clouds.
The only one between
I think San Antonio and San Francisco, and there was Flagstaff, and there was Mars Hill with the little white domes on top.
Of course, Anderson Mesa development had just started, and there were a couple of... Well, there was, I guess...
There was a telescope down there, and I can't remember the exact sequence in which these were moved or built, which was the one connected with the...
lunar mapping program which was going on there.
And that was being done by, what, the Air Force?
That was the Air Force.
It was an Air Force program and it was specifically oriented towards preparing best maps of the moon for the moon landings, future moon landings.
USGS, I guess it was, and Gene Shoemaker's program, they were in Flagstaff around that time.
They were located on the north side of town, a different location.

Yeah, I knew Gene Shoemaker, or got to know him later, because we were both astronaut candidates in 1965, but again, I had no direct connection, just these were interesting programs which were going on in the area.
There was interest
in specifically the preparation for the moon landing.
I didn't associate any of this work with any of the other aspects or any other parts of the solar system.
It was all very much moon-oriented.

Now, I want to take you to Arizona and then your involvement with NASA because the title of this book, God Willing the Creek Don't Rise, it gets printed, is Phoenix, NASA and the Rebirth of Planetary Astronomy.
And you did have a strong connection with NASA, which is how I first got to meet you.
When did this start?
Well, I'd say it started with this letter to NASA Space Science Institute in New York City, and then was referred to Jocelyn Gill, OSS, that branch of OSSA,
Because I was interested in the space program, and I wanted to find out, well, was there any way of getting more closely involved in it?
That's why Jocelyn Gill then invited me to come to Washington, be a consultant in her office, specifically preparing some training manuals or answering questions for the astronauts.
I remember writing a little paper for Jocelyn on...
meteors as a little information paper for the to go to the then Mercury and I guess by then Gemini astronauts.
Out of this meeting with our original contacts with Jocelyn and I don't remember the details I was and I'd always kind of expressed interest in the lunar program
I was referred to a conference that was being held in Chicago.
At O'Hare Airport.
At O'Hare Airport.
And I was the guy that arranged it and chaired it.
Right.
It was on the military orbiting laboratory.
And at this time, there were discussions about merging the Air Force Orbiting Laboratory Program and NASA's plans for orbiting laboratories.
And this was called the MOL conference or something.
And I don't remember exactly how I got invited to it, but I'm sure it was in one way connected with out of Jocelyn Gill's office.
That's where the size of the original space telescope, which is now called Live Space Telescope, got to be 120 inches because Aidan Meinel was there.
And I asked him, what's the biggest diffraction thing we could have in 10 years?
And he said 120 inches.
It was at that meeting that I came in knowing very little about what was going on.
I, of course, had heard of the Air Force program
And I knew there were general long-range plans on the part of NASA.
And it was at that meeting that basically I met Aiden Meinel, who recognized my interest.
And it was then, I believe, was Harlan Smith at that meeting?
Yes.
Both Harlan Smith and Aiden Meinel were at that meeting.
recognized this as a potential field of development, apparently recognized me as somebody who was interested in working in it.
And I got job offers very shortly from both Aden to come to Arizona and from Harlan to come to Texas.
And to basically begin developing
manned space science programs to help them in developing that kind of program.
And I like the atmosphere at Arizona, particularly when I visited one right after the other and accepted Aidan's offer to, again, I hated to leave Lowell.
It was a beautiful place and I was doing good work in galaxy photometry, but I say I needed a change for several reasons.
One was personal with my
coming divorce.
I was divorced in 1964 with custody of two children and then aged two and a half and three and a half.
I needed a change and I was very interested in the space program and said, well, this is a good time to go do something else.
Hayden offered an atmosphere and he's a remarkable person.
So, of course, was Harlan, but
I learned photometry from Harlan at Harvard, which was where I learned how to do photoelectric photometry.
But Arizona offered the opportunity.
The new space sciences building had just been completed.
The section was dedicated to space astronomy that I helped to lay out and built up.
Well, we obtained a NASA grant, initial grant, I guess,
I'm not sure whether I'd have to go back and look at the papers, exactly how my name and Aidan's name were combined.
His philosophy was he would run the classified military side of things, and I would handle the NASA civilian side.
What was NASA giving you the money to do?
Initially, it was experiment or possible design.
I think our original proposal was
a telescope that would float beside Gemini or be carried on Gemini spacecraft and be operated possibly remotely, maybe connected to it.
We wanted to investigate the possibility of carrying a small telescope attached or slightly detached from Gemini and operated in real time.
This then later led to the development of, well, I had two fundamental programs that I worked on.
three actually, that were funded some out of NASA headquarters and some later out of Marshall Space Flight Center.
One was to develop a ultraviolet camera that would operate on a stable platform, stabilized platform, for ultraviolet photography with film recovery.
The idea was to bring back a
as complete a survey of the sky in the UV as possible.
We were developing reflecting filter, interference filter type coatings, and design of a very compact aspheric system for wide field imaging.
And the idea was to do a sky survey, photographic, and bring back the film.
That was one of our key programs.
Here's one thing I've got written down, and I want to ask you before I forget it.
In your opinion, what's NASA like today compared to what it was in the early 60s?
Well, if it was like it was in the early 60s, I would probably still be in it.
What's changed?
Well, as our programs developed, as we got further into experiment development and possibilities,
It became clear that there was, and you'll find this in my discussion with Joe Terowitz, that there was an intense conflict between the manned and the unmanned side of NASA.
And I was interested in the manned side.
I felt that man had a role in space.
I was also strongly oriented toward the lunar program.
and felt that we should get a base on the moon as soon as possible and begin to develop some self-sufficient.
I thought the long range in astronomy really should be founded on the moon.
But what I saw progressively happening was a lot of, well, I was being lost in this battle between manned and unmanned astronomy.
Ultimately, when the things like the Vietnam War developed and so on, everything seemed to be turning downhill.
I didn't see... We didn't get our mission, for example.
We would have flown on Skylab 2.
There had been a Skylab 2, but it was cut off.
We saw the follow-on OIO programs being cut back.
And it looked like, well...
Yes, one could hang on in the field, but the future really didn't look very bright, and especially looked very bright for manned astronomy.
So I basically, after spending quite a bit of NASA money, simply decided that that wasn't a profitable field to work in.
I was on the original planning group for the Large Space Telescope.
I was a member of the Woods Hole study group that led to the...
led to the planning for HST.
But it was a long way downstream.
And I didn't see much opportunity in the interim period.
When you were getting NASA money, how did headquarters handle you?
Did they micromanage?
Do you think they knew what you were doing?
Well, they knew what I was doing.
But I was supported for funny reasons.
I was in the manned space program.
And I had very strong connections with particularly people at Marshall Space Flight Center.
They were interested in developing basically packages for some of their large rockets.
They were interested in basically the origin of the Skylab program, and they wanted packages to put on them.
They weren't getting cooperation from NASA headquarters.
But I was well enough supported that
that there was a feeling at headquarters that they had better support me, had better fund me, so that they would have some control over what was going on.
I received money from Nancy Roman's office, not because my programs were especially favored by them, but so that they could retain some control of what I was doing.
And instead of being funded entirely out of Marshall Space Flight Center, which is where about half of my money came from, there was a lot of... That's what I mean by this conflict between...
the headquarters and the stations, this was very apparent in the work that I was doing.
It did play a role in the way I was funded.
Do you think that astronomers in general do a good job of selling themselves to the public?
And this includes planetary astronomy because I assume that that's part of astronomy.
Well, I think people have become much more aware of this now than they were in the past.
I think in the past, the astronomy has barely been pretty naive in assuming that just the fact that it's good academic science should be sufficient.
So basically, I know, I don't think astronomers have done a very good job of selling themselves to the public.
And it takes a lot of time to do it.
And the problem is, we'll say, the kind of work that I do.
We work as an individual scientist.
You don't have a lot of support, particularly if you do controversial science like I do, with no support, or practically no support.
You don't have time to spend a lot of time doing the popularizing.
What you need is a large enough base
and the kind of support that you can have a public relations person.
You need the kind of people around you who can provide the interface.
And that's an area we have not seen, I don't think, well enough supported.
Scientists have got to be given enough support that they can have some PR people who know how to construct this interface.
Because most of us don't have the time to do it ourselves, nor the knowledge.

do it ourselves to do the proper kind of interface and so i think there's been a lot of very naive scientists who think that all they've got to say is well i mean everybody knows good science should be done that should be sufficient it isn't sufficient you've got to popularize it you've got to present it in a way that uh you'll be
the public would be more enthusiastic about.
Very few scientists know how to do that.
Of course, if you go way back, you know, to the turn of the century, there were some really great promoters around in astronomy, George Orwell.
Now, that all seemed to die, and what I always call the Mount Wilson, the public be damned attitude took over.
Yes, I would agree very much with that, and we have seen the basic, well, it's often called the Mount Wilson or Caltech,
Princeton Access developed, and one had a feeling that, well, if they thought something should be done, that supposedly was all that was necessary.
And there were plenty of us out there who didn't agree with that philosophy.
I mean, Aidan Meinl and I were a good example of who felt that we could have done a lot more science in the man space program.
than, in fact, we ever got a chance to do because the decisions had been made that it was to be done one particular way.
And the manned space program, well, give us your money.
We don't really care about this program.
Just give us the money and we'll go ahead and do the astronomy.
Do you think that attitude is changing now?
Not entirely.
I mean, we still see the same...
fundamental disagreement that astronomy divides into, or science divides into those who are willing to work with the manned program and those who just want unmanned spacecraft.
And there's a role for both.
I've always felt, and I think that the public in many respects is more enthusiastic, or there's a lot of enthusiasm still for manned space-type activity.
And I don't think that resource was ever properly supported by science, that approach.
I can't interview any of the participants in this, so I'm asking everybody that might have an opinion.
What do you think killed planetary astronomy in the early part of this century?
Killed it?
I don't think it was ever killed.
Sure, there was some stuff being done in the 20s and 30s, but
But planetary astronomy was a big part of astronomy at the turn of the century, and then by the time you get to the 1920s, it's not.
Oh, well, okay.
I mean, there was a big shift in interest because the capabilities came along and the knowledge came along to explore stellar astronomy and then extra-galactic astronomy.
I mean, there's always a tendency to move, certainly, or I feel, to move where the frontier is.
And the frontier is usually near the limits of detection
And when the planets are bright and easy to look at.
And I think a lot of the reason that people turned back to planetary astronomy, though, was when the close planetary flybys started coming along.
And people suddenly realized how much more detail and interest or interesting subjects there were that that
It is the space program itself that swung the interest back in the direction of planetary astronomy, because it became clear that so much more could, in fact, be done.
And then we had the new generations of detectors.
And it's kind of interesting.
I think you see these new techniques being focused on very nearby things, like the solar system, and very distant things.
And there's a gap now.
The gap is now in between, where, for example, we're looking at very distant galaxies and ignoring the nearby ones.
except for distance scale calibrations and so on.
We're making the assumption, again, that we understand the nearby thing, and I disagree very strongly on that.

The nearby galaxies are, I think, harbor some very interesting... Well, my own work on the Ritchie equation, of course, is directly relevant there, but you see this leapfrogging technique... From z equals zero to z equals five.
...re-focus your attention on the nearby things.
I think the space program did that.
The primitive early investigations, beginning as early as, say, the Ranger spacecraft, which focused attention again on the detailed surface of the Moon, or the properties of the surface of the Moon.
You see that once a spacecraft had studied the Jupiter system, and now a lot of interesting ground-based observations of the
of the satellites, of the studies of EO and so on, was refocused by the space program.
I don't think the astronomers themselves would have ever, by themselves, would have ever gotten as enthusiastic about the solar system if it hadn't been for the space program.
Recently, so you think that NASA money, really, for probes and supporting ground-based astronomy really brought back planetary astronomy?
Yes, I think I feel that very strongly.
I don't think it was the astronomers themselves, even given the detectors.
Well, some, I'm sure, would have looked at the planets, but it was the excitement generated by the space program that brought, well, probably a lot of people had been trained or trained
their job opportunities were conditional upon the availability of space money.
The number of astronomers trained was increased considerably because of the space program.
Recently, a lot of people have been getting a lot of publicity, and evidently money, by working on topics such as search for extraterrestrial intelligence,

other solar search for other solar systems uh the ozone hole uh on the earth's atmosphere and killer comets and asteroids you think they're overdoing it well i think these are all valid fields of investigation and i think the reason why some of these are emphasized or why the focus is there is because they are programs which you can popularize now i don't think that's
that should be the judge of how you support science.
And in a sense, yeah, I think I would agree with you.
I think some of these are overemphasized in the sense of, well, the public will support this, or we can put it in such a way that the public will recognize its, quote, importance.
So, okay, that's a good way to go.
I think many of these, part of this work is motivated by
We need money, and this is a way to get money.
And not necessarily because it's necessarily the best science.
I'm sure that if you ask a general cross-section of scientists what are the best problems to concentrate on, that these would be mentioned, but they certainly wouldn't be the unique ones.
And I think things like the SETI program, there's a lot of interest in this, and it is scientifically important.
On the other hand, it's a little bit like the search for missing mass.
You can put an awful lot of effort into it for very little return.
And there's some balance point.
in terms of what is the reasonable amount of resource and effort to put into this until you get some indication that there's something that really needs to be followed up.

This includes planetary astronomy because we all sink or swim in the same ocean.
Are we sinking?

We see too much...
Well, I think there's a little bit of fear out there.

uh i think people are not looking objectively at the science anymore but they're saying well what can i get money for there's too much focus on what can i get money for and too little on regardless of the money what science should we what are the what are the things that we must preserve in terms of science there are a few odd people like myself who would i will pursue what i think
should be done in science, I don't have outside support.
So I can speak a little bit objectively.
I don't worry about protecting my resources because my resources are my own salary.
And I mean, I came to this meeting, I paid my own way.

I don't have support even from my own institution.
Well, the institution doesn't have the money to give me.
Everything comes from these outside grants.
And when you do controversial work, it's very difficult to get these outside grants.
